sections.title: Stay Agile Through Transitions
sections.subtitle: Adapt your budget for milestones like moving, career shifts, or growing family needs

sections.title: In This Session
items: Forecast the financial impact of major life events
Identify temporary vs. permanent expense changes

sections.title: Change Requires a New Baseline
sections.content: Big life moments—new jobs, relocations, caregiving—demand a fresh look at cash flow. Anticipating costs early prevents panic and keeps you anchored to long-term goals.

points.title: Timeline Mapping
points.description: Lay out key dates (start/finish) to align expenses and income changes.

points.title: Scenario Analysis
points.description: Draft best, likely, and worst-case budgets so you're ready for curveballs.

points.title: Communication
points.description: Share updates with partners or accountability buddies to stay coordinated.

sections.title: Emergency + Cushion
sections.content: Pair your standard emergency fund with a transition buffer equal to one month's projected new expenses.

sections.title: Cash Flow Shock Absorbers
sections.content: Pause nonessential sinking funds, renegotiate recurring bills, or pick up interim income streams while you adjust. Remember that some expenses are one-time setup costs (moving fees) while others alter your monthly baseline (childcare).

sections.title: Transition Blueprint
steps: Name the upcoming life change and list associated expenses (one-time and ongoing).
Estimate income shifts during the transition period and note any gaps.
Create three budget scenarios (optimistic, realistic, stretch) and note triggers for switching between them.
Decide which discretionary categories to scale back temporarily and for how long.
Schedule a midpoint review (date) to measure progress and adjust the plan.

sections.title: Document Lessons
sections.content: After the transition, record what worked and what surprised you—future you will thank you during the next change.
